message.content: This question requires knowledge about sustainable shopping practices and reducing waste. The correct answer is (A) cloth satchel. Bringing your own cloth satchel or reusable shopping bag is a way to avoid using single-use plastic bags, which contribute to waste and pollution. Option (B), greedy nature, is irrelevant and does not promote sustainable shopping. Option (C) promotes the use of one-use paper bags, which also contribute to waste, although they are generally considered more environmentally friendly than plastic bags. Option (D), disposable plastic bag, is the opposite of avoiding waste and is not a sustainable option.

This question requires knowledge about sustainable practices and reducing waste. One example of avoiding waste when grocery shopping is to bring your own cloth satchel. By using a reusable bag, you can eliminate the need for one-use paper bags or disposable plastic bags, which contribute to waste. Option (B) is incorrect because having a "greedy nature" is unrelated to avoiding waste when grocery shopping. Option (C) and (D) are also incorrect because they promote the use of single-use bags, which contribute to waste.

This question requires knowledge about sustainable practices and reducing waste. By bringing your own cloth satchel to the grocery store, you can avoid using single-use plastic or paper bags, which contribute to waste. Option (B) is incorrect because being greedy has nothing to do with grocery shopping or waste reduction. Option (C) is incorrect because one-use paper bags are still contributing to waste, albeit less than disposable plastic bags. Option (D) is incorrect because disposable plastic bags are not an example of avoiding waste.

Bringing your own cloth satchel is an example of avoiding waste because it can be reused multiple times, reducing the need for single-use paper bags or disposable plastic bags. Option (B) is incorrect because a greedy nature does not contribute to avoiding waste. Option (C) is incorrect because one-use paper bags, although better than disposable plastic bags, still contribute to waste and deforestation. Option (D) is incorrect because disposable plastic bags are a major source of pollution and have harmful effects on the environment.

Option (B), "greedy nature," is unrelated and not applicable to grocery shopping.
